title: The Best (UPDATE:FIXED?) Smartphone/Tablet e-reader
comment: I've been using fbreader since symbian and have always found it to be the most accessible and compatible e-reader. For those having difficulty getting it to find newly added books to external SD cards, I've found the best workaround is to use 'Browse file system' --> 'Entire file system' --> 'storage' --> (the name of your external card, e.g. 'sdcard1'). Browse to the folder you added your book(s), and if you open any book in the folder, it will recognize and add all new books in the folder to your library. UPDATE 1/14/15: Application had been freezing a lot in library view/browse  with 2.2.2 update. FBreader devs had a quick turnaround with 2.2.2.1 update, which unfortunately did not fix the issue for me. Fortunately, was able to resolve the issue by  clearing all app data and uninstalling the app, then manually selecting the library, fonts and cache location in 'settings'. This may be related to how Android 5.0.1 has disabled write access to \storage\emulated\0, so I can't blame the devs for what could be a problem caused by google's persistent tinkering. If you're having issues with Android 5.0.1, it's worth trying this workaround
Sorry for this. Update 2.2.2.1 fixes the crash. Already in the Play, will be available for users in a few hours.

title: Best ereader
comment: I have tried them all -- and frankly, they are all pretty good.  Two things make FBReader "the best":   - close control over text formatting. I read on several different devices, and each has a different "ideal distance" and therefore needs different formatting, including two columns on my big tablet. With FBReader, I can fine-tune each device. - integration with calibre (using the plug-in available in the Play Store). Everyone who has a lot of ebooks eventually needs calibre for editing meta-data, converting formats, and whatever. Having direct access from FBReader to my calibre library is great!

title: The best out of free & paid e-readers.
comment: it's not pretty, it could use a better looking library view but even after saying that, after trying every reader i could get my hands on (free & paid) it is the best reader ever with perfect options& the best addons. When it comes to reading books & importing books it is the best. It lets u view books by name, author, recent, series, folder, etc. it's ez to back up & share books. The speech plugin i use with ivona text to speech is awesome. It's like having a library of ebooks or audio books so you can read the book & when you have to go somewhere or are too busy to read you can listen to it like you would an audio book, you even have the choice to read along if you wanted. There's an addon to sync with calibre so you can have access to all your books, there's an add-on to sync books & your place u left off with dropbox. It lets u choose background, text, link, highlight colors etc. There are fonts to choose but it'd be cool if it let u scan & use your own. I can't believe all of the reader apps I've tried& installed, this one is like the best features of them all in 1 no-nonsense app with a very ez interface & menu. I couldn't believe it's perfect&free. I REQUEST GOODREADS plugin

title: The Best I've Found, But...
comment: So, this is a GREAT e reader, better than iBooks I used on my old Apple tablet. So I dunno what all I heard about no e-reader options for Android before I switched was about. This app has great display options including a night mode and brightness adjusting via swiping the right edge of the screen, it can prevent your tablet screen from shutting off (or you can choose to prevent it until a certain % of battery life remains and then move into battery life mode) . It can handle ALMOST all of the formats I want, great on the eyes, great bookmarking for coming back to a specific place, and it automatically saves your place in the book when you close the app or switch to read a different book. Hyperlinks in your book table of contents or in the text giving a link to an Appendix are easily followed and you can move right back to where you were in the book. You can organize your library on the disk and access books via the file tree for easy organizing. This is the best e-reader I have found.  1 problem - it can't read PDF files. It doesn't even see them on the file tree when looking at your library. You have to convert the files. ADD PDF SUPPORT PLEASE!!

title: Very poor handling of .mobi files
comment: Extremely poor handling of .mobi format results in constant error toasters indicating "API Errors", long pauses, and very sluggish performance.  With some help from the TTS plugin development team, was able to find a workaround -- .epub seems to be handled somewhat better -- performance is better, and I see the errors less frequently.  Very frustrating.  The format really shouldn't be supported at all if it's done this sloppily, and the error messages are so poor that it took me forever -- and the help of a plugin developer not associated with this app -- to find a workaround.

title: Great app but could be improved
comment: FBReader is great because its a free, robust ereader, however it lacks a bit of polish, particularly in default theme (a dithered sepia effect with serif font), the overwhelming number of settings, the lack of launcher for file formats.  For example I tap an epub through a file explorer and FBReader doesn't appear as an app which can handle it (Moon+ does but not FBReader). Instead I have to move the epub to my book directory to see it. Also it has 3 baked in font styles and while it can handle other fonts it doesn't look in /system/fonts by default even though other ereaders do.  Once configured it works really well but it could do with the usability polish and some sensible defaults.

title: It is very good but...
comment: ...it needs to be able to honour the author's CSS more completely. I have published an ebook version of a technical book that ran to 400+ pages in print. Chapter titles, section titles, subsection titles, links and notes within the text were all carefully styled to be obvious to the reader. Unfortunately they all look pretty much the same in FBReader (apart from size) as well as most other readers for Android. User control of fonts, colours, backgrounds etc. is all very fine for customising the 'reading experience' of a novel or a book of poems but it detracts considerably from the reading of a technical book - which is not generally read for enjoyment but for education. Not being able to readily spot links and section titles slows down the absorption of the content. The iBooks App is much better in this respect. Two things are critical for reading a complex technical book on a phone (or small tablet)... 1. Respect for the author's CSS as indicated above. 2. The ability to zoom, scroll and rotate diagrams and tables for viewing on a small screen FBReader does a good job of item 2 but not of item 1.

title: Solves all of the other e-readers' problems!
comment: I tried the Kindle, Aldiko and Kobo apps, but none of them could do everything I wanted from an e-reader. This one's different, in a good way.   It can adjust fonts as much as I could want — it has options for changing between mono, serif and sans serif, along with as many sizes as anyone's likely to need — and has an interesting range of options. There are several possible background colours, including a couple of brown ones by default, and then there's an option for choosing your own using RGB values.  It reads .mobi files, which is good for people who want to switch from the Kindle app to something allowing the user more control. Finding the Kindle library can be a bit tricky; it involves guesswork as to where the device has hidden the files.  I'd really recommend this app.

title: Very good reader, simple and yet fully featured
comment: This is a great reader, very light, simple and yet fully featured, it has many customization for reading ebooks, such as margin, font sizes, colors, night mode, brightness control, etc. perfect for my nexus 7.  It does not have a nice shelf view and all those "nice and fancy" looks of other readers, but don't under estimate it, it's a very complete e-reader. Works great with epub files. title: mobi files badly displayed, otherwise top
comment: Although FBReader supports .mobi files (that's why I chose this reader), the reading experience is not good. FBReader doesn't show page breaks and doesn't show titles in different font sizes, nor additional line spacing. So you lose a lot of structure which might hamper your reading pleasure. Other than that, this reader performs well. Since I work with Calibre, I convert my non-DRM files and simply use the .epub format instead of .mobi. The app runs stable. I like the light dimming by running your finger up or down on the left side and the choice of night or day display. I would like to see the five dictionary choices expanded, allowing you to specify your own dictionary.

title: Annoyingly slow startup. Otherwise OK.
comment: It takes way, way too long for the program to start and load the book and display the position you were at when you left it. (About 10 times as long as QReader on my old E61.) It should pre-cache the page you left it at so it could show it *immediately* upon startup.  It is impossible to disable the tap/flick page flip (I just want to use the volume buttons without the page flipping if I touch the screen by mistake).  There is no sensible progress indicator unit to accompany the progress bar -- percentage and/or kchars would be nice. (It only shows pages, which is just silly since the page numbers change when you change the settings.)  There is no setting for how many "overlapping" lines to use when flipping the page (I'd like to have 1 or 2 lines, but now it shows none).  On the plus side it supports white text on a black background (great for reading in bed or with an AMOLED screen or with a transflective screen in sunlight).

title: It grows on you.
comment: Very ugly defaults on a Nexus 7. Starts off with unnecessarily tiny text and a tedious textured background that reminds me of a personal website from 1995. Dig into the settings, though, and you'll find all sorts of options to get FBReader looking and feeling great (for any value of "great"). If you don't like this app at first, make sure you spend a minute or two tweaking it: you might change your mind :)  I just have two problems right now: the page curl animation looks terrible on my device (seems it doesn't affect the text), and I am limited to the Droid fonts in the appearance settings, so I'm not really 100% satisfied. title: This is the reader app you want
comment: I have found a version for almost every platform I use, Windows, Linux, Zaurus. It does not have the eye candy that some readers have, but it can open my ebook collection that spans 20 years, including palm format, epub, mobi and plain text. The integrated manybooks and smashwords libraries can get you many free classics quickly while you are getting your modern collection started. Page flipping with the volume control is sweet, and I use this for reading during down time on the train or waiting in line so I get more reading time in than if I were just using my full size ereader. Lacks a couple nice things, like percentage read. This is important to sync across devices manually, since page numbers will be different with each device. It would be fun to have more font and background options like the eye candy readers, but then they choke on many ebooks that this one opens fine, so overall a great deal.

It is pretty flawless really, it is very customizable allowing you to change everything from backgrounds & margins to page turn animation and speed. I will almost certainly stick with FBReader.  However it's worth saying that the default display settings are not great! Honestly I think Aldiko really has this right. Thanks to FBReader being so flexible though you can have the advantages of FBReader (faster page turns, different animations, smaller file size, etc). My recommended display settings are Background color: Block Colour, white (255,255,255) Margins: 80 (all the way around) Font Face: Droid serif Font size: 20  Pretty sure everything else can be left default to fit your preferences!

title: Open and usable
comment: When I looked for my first e-book reader, I quickly saw that 1. I wanted not to be dependent on proprietary services or content formats, and 2. that most readers with good basic features did force those dependencies on users. Also, I wanted an app that needed few permissions and no invasive ones. Solutions were few, and FBReader quickly stood out as being the only one for me. Since I get e-books directly from distributors, I don't need a reader to download them. So I stripped FBReader of the 'full internet access' permission. It still works perfectly; no crashes! The UI needs some polish. But in the full screen mode I use, with no OS chrome or app UI shown, the reading experience is smooth. Hyphenation needs help, too. ;^) My thanks go to the developer for an excellent tool.
